awd_titl_txt: EAGER: A Quantitative Theory for Technology Evolution and Innovation
awd_abstract_narration:
Technology innovation is critical to the social welfare, health, economy, and security of the USA and the world. A fundamental understating of innovation is elusive. It can be observed, but it is hard to predict, and even harder to execute. The difficulty in understanding and executing innovation rests in part on the complexity of the technology ecosystem. For example, the invention and development of Corning's Gorilla Glass supports the smartphone which in turn synergizes with social media to drive new types of software development. At the same time, observation of a single technology through time shows an evolutionary improvement in performance. Compared to the first generation, current smartphones store more photographs and operate longer without the need for charging. This EArly-Concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award supports fundamental research to create a mathematical theory that describes technology performance evolution and, simultaneously, ecological synergies between technologies. The created theoretical model will have sufficient fidelity and causal indicators such that one can predict and effect innovation. This new theory will inform individual and enterprise-scale technology innovation. Also, by knowing the impact and by predicting the evolution of new technologies, policy makers can make sound investment and funding decisions for key research initiatives. The enhanced understanding will also help public policy officials develop appropriate regulations and incentive structures for future technology development.  

The technology ecosystem model of technologies and their interaction is modeled using generalized Lotka-Volterra (L-V) population models. The intellectual impact of this work includes the extensions made to the general format of L-V equations to connect them to microscale technology performance improvement (the improved performance of a single technology). The microscale technology evolution model will follow S-curve trends, but in fact be created with L-V equations. This general model of technology evolution will be extended using theories from The Theory of Inventive Problem Solving (TIPS). The hypothesis is that this multiscale, hierarchical, L-V model will be able to capture the ecosystem type interaction of engineered products and technologies as well as performance evolution.

por.por_cntn:
Technology evolution describes variation in technology performance over time. It is critical to the social welfare, health, economy, and security of the world. Designers, entrepreneurs, and policy makers have great interest in understanding the history of a technology performance improvement and subsequently forecast the future technology performance accordingly, which is called technology evolution prediction or technological forecasting.

 Several descriptive models are commonly used for technology evolution prediction, but they have several drawbacks. More than thirty descriptive models for technology evolution prediction exist, and users often have to go through tedious procedures to select an appropriate model for their specific problem. Moreover, most of parameters in these models lack physical meaning or interpretation. The models often are at best curve fits rather than descriptors of causality. Importantly, most technology performance models consider that a technology evolves in isolation and doesn’t interconnect with other technologies. In this research, the investigators create a theoretical model that has sufficient fidelity to include sufficient causal indicators of technology evolution such that one can predict, and in some cases, direct technology evolution.

The technology evolution model is a general ecosystem model of technology integration. An ecosystem model is appropriate, as technologies exist through relationships with other technologies. Analogous to natural ecosystem relationships, the interaction between system and system component technologies can be symbiosis, commensalism, and amensalism. These relationships are captured through the interaction terms of Lotka-Volterra equations. Thus, a multiscale, hierarchical in nature, Lotka-Volterra system of equations is able to capture the ecosystem type interaction of engineered products and technologies.

The Lotka-Volterra model is validated on existing system technologies of commercial passenger airplanes and concrete based skyscapers. The Lotka-Volterra ecosystem model elegantly captures the symbiotic relationship between passenger airplane (system technology) and aero-engine (component technology). The result shows that the data fitting and prediction performance of our Lotka-Volterra ecosystem model significantly exceed that of the extant technology evolution models.

Key contributions of this work are the creation of a theoretical model that reveals the causal factors (e.g. R&D investment and the development of different component technologies) of technology evolution. Also, the model measures the contribution from each factor quantitatively and provides technological forecasting for decision makers.

This research has significant impact on designers, entrepreneurs, and policy makers. Specifically, by knowing the causal factors and by predicting the technology evolution, designers can estimate the lifetime of their product and integrate appropriate component technologies into their product; entrepreneurs can make sound investment and funding decisions on key research initiatives; policy makers can allocate resources optimally and develop effective incentive structures for future technology development.
